abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Electricity Market
            Project for Romania were as follows: outcomes were highly
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: competitively designed and organized competitive
            bidding among qualified contractors gave Compania Nationala
            de Transport al Energiei Electrice (Transelectrica) good
            performance at competent prices, well below original cost
            Estimates, also self-evident but nevertheless a lesson worth
            noting. The development of a functioning electricity market
            is a complex undertaking which Romania, the Government and
            the project's three executing agencies, accomplished
            successfully with the support of the project. A clear
            strategy (the road map); competent and committed staff in
            three executing agencies; close coordination between the
            agencies, with the Government, and with the European
            Commission and the Bank; and support by highly qualified
            consultants with hands-on experience were the key
            ingredients for Romania's success. Transelectrica
            experiences and expects increasing challenges, difficulties,
            and delays in its projects involving land acquisition. To
            mitigate land acquisition delay risks, the Government could
            explore amendments to Romania's land acquisition
            framework for those energy projects which the Government
            deems to be priority projects of public/national interest.
            This can be done by streamlining procedures and updating the
            law in force, in order to avoid delays due to disputes
            settlement over compensation levels.

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Electricity Market Project :
            environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Romania Electricity Market Project sets forth the plan for
            mitigating potentially negative impacts. During
            construction, spray with water using pressurized water jets
            to control dust and earth removal activities, erect a dust
            protective barrier, and cover equipment and machinery. To
            reduce noise, execute during the daytime and avoid exceeding
            noise limits. Wastes shall be separated and stored within
            the substation area: collect waste oil in metallic tanks
            located on concrete foundations and dispose of solid waste
            in specially treated areas. Afterwards, remove waste and
            reuse or store waste. Unrecoverable inert wastes shall be
            taken to government approved dump sites. Remove topsoil and
            dispose of oil-contaminated soils in special areas. Restore
            sites by filling holes, leveling soil, and covering grass.
            PCB contaminated soil shall be removed and treated by
            licensed contractors using internationally accepted methods.
            During project operation, collect wastewater according to
            quality requirements. Alleviate air pollution by installing
            technologically capable machinery and using low-sulfur
            content fuel. Equip the diesel unit with a collecting tank
            and oil/water separator. Procure new equipment to decrease noise.

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Electricity Market Project :
            sixth quality at entry assessment (QEA6)  - investment
            lending questionnaire

abstracts.cdata!:
The panel rated this Electricity Market
            Project for Romania as highly satisfactory. This project is
            an excellent example of a quick response to an immediate
            request by the client for assistance in meeting the urgent
            need for transmission investments and support for
            development of its power market. Strong government support
            at the highest levels insured both rapid processing and a
            high quality product. The Bank, on its part, was able to
            field an experienced team able to draw on the Bank's
            global experience, particularly in the development of
            competitive power markets. This is an area in which the Bank
            has a strong competitive advantage and consequently, high
            value added. The project was appraised in a highly
            professional manner with all aspects receiving careful
            attention. The project is also notable for its close
            coordination with other donors. The European institutions
            are active in this country and responsible for most of the
            investments made. They have accepted the Bank's
            preeminent role in market development and have closely
            coordinated their investments with the Bank. More
            importantly, the country itself has taken on the major role
            in coordinating the various donors and has produced a road
            map outlining sector policy as a part of the preparation for
            this project. This project was not originally in the
            program. The country assistance strategy (CAS) assumed this
            was a sector in which the Bank could withdraw because the
            international private sector would be forthcoming with the
            necessary resources. This assumption proved to be incorrect
            and it took both time and pressure from the country to alter
            the Bank's perspective.  The Bank probably needs to be
            more flexible in its programming, particularly in middle
            income countries that are capable of identifying their need
            to change priorities in response to changing circumstances.

10030691.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Electricity Market Project for Romania is to develop a
            well-functioning wholesale electricity market with the aim
            of: (a) putting in place a transparent and predictable
            commercial and regulatory framework and a power exchange
            that will facilitate electricity trading within a
            competitive national, regional and eventually European
            market; and (b) improving the efficiency and reliability of
            the transmission system in order to support trading and
            supply electricity at least cost to consumers. A
            well-functioning wholesale electricity market is an integral
            component of Romania's strategy to attract and sustain
            private sector participation in power sector renewal,
            especially for the refurbishment o f power distribution and
            generation assets, and to develop a more efficient and
            increasingly competitive power sector. There are two main
            project components. The project will be implemented by
            Transelectrica (Romania's grid company and power system
            operator), OPCOM ("Operator Commercial," the
            subsidiary of the national power company and Romania's
            power market operator),  and ANRE (the regulatory agency for
            electricity and heat). The first component, the investment
            component, rehabilitates the Iernut substation and Fundeni
            Substation, and finances engineering and supervision
            consulting services. The second component , the technical
            assistance component, 1) designs and implements the
            regulatory framework (commercial code, market rules, and
            price-caps for network services) for the new Electricity
            Trading Platform; 2) designs, pilot tests, and implements
            the new Electricity Trading Platform through the OPCOM Power
            Exchange; and 3) provides institutional support to Transelectrica.
